message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including unintentional weight loss, irregularly irregular rhythm on auscultation, and an enlarged thyroid with no lymphadenopathy or bruit, suggest the most likely diagnosis is toxic multinodular goiter. The scintigraphy shows patchy uptake with multiple hot and cold areas, which is consistent with this diagnosis. Graves' disease would show diffuse increased uptake on scintigraphy, while Hashimoto's thyroiditis and subacute granulomatous thyroiditis are unlikely given the absence of anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody and the patient's clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including unintentional weight loss, and the presence of an irregularly irregular rhythm suggest hyperthyroidism. The low TSH level and high T4 level suggest that the thyroid gland is overactive. The patchy uptake with multiple hot and cold areas on nuclear scintigraphy is consistent with a diagnosis of toxic multinodular goiter. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is characterized by an enlarged thyroid gland, but nuclear scintigraphy typically shows diffusely decreased uptake.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has evidence of hyperthyroidism due to low TSH and high T4 levels, but the thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin is absent which rules out Graves' disease. The absence of anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody is also not consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Patchy uptake with multiple hot and cold areas suggests a toxic multinodular goiter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest a diagnosis of toxic multinodular goiter. The presence of an irregularly irregular rhythm and enlarged thyroid also support this diagnosis. Graves’ disease and Hashimoto’s thyroiditis would have different laboratory findings, and subacute granulomatous thyroiditis typically presents with pain and tenderness in the thyroid gland.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hyperthyroidism, and among the options, only toxic multinodular goiter can cause an irregularly irregular heartbeat and multiple hot and cold patches on nuclear scintigraphy. Graves’ disease will show thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin, Hashimoto’s thyroiditis will show anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody, and subacute granulomatous thyroiditis will show low T4 level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of unintentional weight loss, an irregularly irregular rhythm, and a markedly enlarged thyroid suggest hyperthyroidism. The low TSH level and high T4 level also support this. Absence of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin and anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies rules out Graves' disease and Hashimoto's thyroiditis. The patchy uptake with multiple hot and cold areas suggests a toxic multinodular goiter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with weight loss, an irregularly irregular rhythm, and an enlarged thyroid. The laboratory results show a low TSH level and high T4 level, which suggests hyperthyroidism. The nuclear scintigraphy showed multiple hot and cold areas, which is consistent with toxic multinodular goiter. Graves’ disease would have presented with positive thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin and Hashimoto’s thyroiditis would have presented with positive anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody. Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis would have presented with a painful, tender thyroid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The irregularly irregular rhythm on auscultation of the heart suggests atrial fibrillation, which is commonly associated with hyperthyroidism. The patient has an enlarged thyroid with multiple hot and cold areas on nuclear scintigraphy, which suggests a nodular thyroid gland. This and the absence of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin and anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody suggest the most likely diagnosis is a toxic multinodular goiter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hyperthyroidism, and the laboratory tests show low TSH and high T4 levels. The irregularly irregular rhythm on auscultation of the heart suggests atrial fibrillation, which is associated with toxic multinodular goiter. Nuclear scintigraphy confirms the presence of multiple hot and cold areas, which is also characteristic of toxic multinodular goiter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an enlarged thyroid, weight loss, and an irregularly irregular rhythm, which are consistent with hyperthyroidism. The low thyroid-stimulating hormone level and high T4 level suggest a primary hyperthyroidism rather than secondary or tertiary. The absent thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin and anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody suggest that the most likely diagnosis is toxic multinodular goiter, which is the second most common cause of hyperthyroidism after Graves’ disease.
